title: Seminar 1
text:
Basics of markdown
Check out this link to learn more about the basics of Markdown.
For example, you can make lists;

item 1
item 2

Note, be sure to add a line-break before and after the list.
ordered/numbered lists;

number 1
number 2

use LaTeX; \[
  Y = X\beta + u
\] even, inline \(Y = X\beta + u\).

title: Seminar 1
text:
Adding code
Load tidyverse library. Check this link to learn how to hide code-blocks and compress messages/warnings.
Create graph

car_frame <- mpg
ggplot(data = car_frame) +
  geom_point(mapping=aes(x=displ, y=hwy)) +
  geom_smooth(mapping=aes(x=displ, y=hwy))

`geom_smooth()` using method = 'loess' and formula = 'y ~ x'





My graph

title: Seminar 1
text:
Quarto
I would recommend that you investigate the cool things you can do with Quarto.

title: Seminar 1
text:
Git and GitHub
Here’s a great youtube on Git and GitHub.
The basic steps, I used:

Create a GitHub account.
Install Git on your computer. This will include an app called Git Bash. You can also check out Git Desktop. I have found it easier to follow the steps below, which can be executed from Git Bash or the terminal within RStudio.
I typically follow the following steps laid out on this blog under the heading “Type 2: Work on your project locally then create the repository on GitHub and push it to remote.”
